{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3023454,"name":"Joshua Epperson","username":"jepperson","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/74df32/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-15T05:18:41.582Z","cooked":"

The question is in the title, I have my shooter code implemented in command and was wondering for the low ring shot if I could just have it update some variable and then schedule the shooter command in initialize. I’d test it myself but I don’t have access to the robot at the moment.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2022-03-15T05:18:41.582Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":102,"readers_count":101,"score":60.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":405762,"topic_slug":"can-you-schedule-a-command-within-a-command","display_username":"Joshua Epperson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-you-schedule-a-command-within-a-command/405762/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3023475,"name":"Nolan","username":"Quake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/quake/{size}/236072_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-15T06:10:43.599Z","cooked":"

To answer the topic title, yes-- read about the ScheduleCommand and ProxyScheduleCommand here. As the docs explain, though, this is useful for scheduling some command while inside a command group that you don’t want to take the requirements of. I’m not sure what you’re trying to accomplish, could you explain a bit more? It sounds like you might be looking for default commands.

(FYI the functionality of ScheduleCommand is literally just an instant command that performs command.schedule())

jepperson:

I’d test it myself but I don’t have access to the robot at the moment.

Have you tried to use simulation? Even with 0 extra additions you should be able to see what motor controllers are being set to. Now I don’t know your whole system so maybe currently a sensor needs to be read or something which is a minor inconvenience to set.
